title: What are some good listening activities? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you’re looking to become a better listener, there are several things you can try. I learned a great deal from taking an Active Listening course that was part of a Counselling program at a local college - it was a REALLY good decision. It’s helped me in numerous areas of my life both personally and professionally. Next time, when you find yourself listening to a friend about their day or perhaps a grievance, practice the following: Don’t give advice. (And especially don’t think of things as they talk!)Hear what they say, consider their perspective and what they might have felt. Never AssumeIt may seem obvious but never assume you know how a person is feeling. It’s tempting to say, “You must have been so angry” or “Wow - that’s humiliating.” Instead, use phrases like, “it seems like”, or “it sounds as if”. You may be surprised at what else is going on for that person and they will feel more inclined to share with you (because you don’t cut them off). Allow some silenceIn my experience, I’ve found that we often think we need to “fill the gaps” during periods of silence. In these moments, we are likely going to offer advice or start talking about our on experiences. Instead, I offer to try and allow some silence. STAY PRESENT (ie. don’t start thinking about your weekend plans or what to say next). The person may need some time to process and often things will come up and they’ll start talking again. Ask Open-Ended QuestionsIf there’s a VERY long silence or it seems like the person is feeling shut-down or unsure, ask an open-ended question. This means they cannot answer the question with a simple “yes” or “now”. For example, “What did you feel after you heard the news?” is open-ended, versus “Were you angry?” (closed question). Hope that helps!
